rationale:
The predicate <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> is used to specify the type of the subject. In this case, the subject is <http://example.org/x1> and the object is <http://example.org/t1>.

However, there is no direct link between <http://example.org/x1> and <http://example.org/t1>. Instead, there are two triples where <http://example.org/x1> is the subject, <ex:r2> is the predicate, and <ex:y1> and <ex:y2> are the objects.

Additionally, we know that <ex:r2> is a functional property, which means that each subject can have at most one object for this predicate. Therefore, <http://example.org/x1> cannot be of type <http://example.org/t1> because it is related to <ex:y1> and <ex:y2> through <ex:r2>.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> indicates that the subject and object are equivalent or identical. In this case, the subject and object are both <http://example.org/y1>. Therefore, the triple is true.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> is used to indicate that two resources are identical. In this case, the subject and object are the same URI, <http://example.org/x1>. Therefore, the triple is true, as it indicates that the resource <http://example.org/x1> is the same as itself.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> is used to specify the type of a resource. In this case, the subject <http://example.org/y2> is said to be of type <http://example.org/t2>.

The property ex:r2 has a domain of ex:t1 and a range of ex:t2, and it is functional, meaning that each subject can have at most one object.

From the given facts, we can see that ex:x1 is related to both ex:y1 and ex:y2 through the property ex:r2. Since ex:r2 is functional, it means that ex:x1 can only be related to one resource of type ex:t2 through ex:r2.

In this hypothetical world, if ex:y2 is of type ex:t2, then it would mean that ex:x1 is related to two resources of type ex:t2 through ex:r2, which contradicts the fact that ex:r2 is functional.

Therefore, in this hypothetical world, <http://example.org/y2> cannot be of type <http://example.org/t2>.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> 
indicates that the subject and object are the same individual. 
In this case, the subject and object are both <http://example.org/y2>. 
Since the subject and object are the same, the triple is true.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> is used to specify the type of a resource. In this case, the subject <http://example.org/y1> is assigned the type <http://example.org/t2>.

The triple ex:x1 ex:r2 ex:y1 states that the resource ex:y1 is related to ex:x1 via the property ex:r2. Similarly, the triple ex:x1 ex:r2 ex:y2 states that the resource ex:y2 is also related to ex:x1 via the property ex:r2.

The property ex:r2 has a domain of ex:t1 and a range of ex:t2, as specified by the triples ex:r2 rdfs:domain ex:t1 and ex:r2 rdfs:range ex:t2.

Since ex:y1 and ex:y2 are related to ex:x1 via the property ex:r2, and ex:r2 has a range of ex:t2, it follows that both ex:y1 and ex:y2 must be of type ex:t2.

Therefore, the triple Subject: <http://example.org/y1> Predicate: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> Object: <http://example.org/t2> is true.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> indicates that the subject and object are equivalent.
Given the information provided, there is no direct or indirect relationship between <http://example.org/y1> and <http://example.org/y2> using the property <http://example.org/r2>.
However, the property <http://example.org/r2> is functional, meaning that for a given subject, there can be at most one object.
Since <http://example.org/x1> has two different objects, <http://example.org/y1> and <http://example.org/y2>, for the same property <http://example.org/r2>, this violates the functional property constraint.
Therefore, the knowledge graph triple is not true in this hypothetical world.

The predicate <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> indicates that the subject and object are equivalent.
The triple ex:x1 ex:r2 ex:y1 and ex:x1 ex:r2 ex:y2 state that ex:y1 and ex:y2 are connected by the functional property ex:r2.
Since ex:r2 is a functional property, it means that for a given value of ex:x1, there can only be one value of ex:y.
Therefore, if ex:y1 and ex:y2 are connected by the same ex:x1 and ex:r2, they must be equivalent, and the triple <http://example.org/y1> <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> <http://example.org/y2> is true.
